awd_titl_txt: ENGAGING IN STEM EDUCATION WITH BIG DATA ANALYTICS AND TECHNOLOGIES: A ROWAN-COVE INITIATIVE
awd_abstract_narration:
Large amounts of data have become available across fields in science, industry, government, healthcare and pharmaceuticals. Big data analytics and technologies hold tremendous promise to boost economic productivity, enhance national security and improve the quality of life. Recognizing the acute need for big data technology, the aim of this proposal is to create a national model by developing multi-year curricular material that allows course content in separate classes to be naturally inter-connected. In collaboration with industry (Lockheed Martin Inc. and HP Enterprise), this project designs a series of laboratory experiments in big data analytics and technologies that become more complex from the freshmen to the senior year. The proposed approach will cut across artificial course boundaries and introduce fundamental, contemporary and multidisciplinary big data concepts through a series of problem-oriented laboratory experiments. Students will also gain a better knowledge of policy, ethical, and societal impact issues of big data.

The collaboration with Palmyra Cove Education Foundation will bring big data activities to K-12 and further evaluate the educational impact and increase related dissemination efforts. The activities run at Cove will excite K-12 students about engineering and enhance teacher expertise in mathematics, science and technology. Palmyra Cove will reach out to local underrepresented K-12 school districts targeting women and minorities. The Foundation will also organize a workshop for undergraduate students, university faculty and K-12 students and teachers on big data as applied to environmental engineering and the geosciences. The results will be disseminated through technical and educational conferences and journal articles.

por.por_cntn:
This project designed, implemented, and institutionalized a multi-year curricular material that focuses on enhancing and evaluating STEM education - across engineering disciplines - via multidisciplinary research modules, in the emerging field of Big Data analytics and computational intelligence, and in collaboration with industry and federal agencies, including Hewlett Packard Enterprise, Lockheed Martin, and the Federal Aviation Administration. Although the original proposal included three Engineering Departments (Electrical and Computer, Civil and environmental and Chemical engineering), offerings of research projects in Big Data are now established in Biomedical Engineering and Mechanical Engineering as well. More than 25 junior/senior research projects - involving Big Data analytics, models, and technologies - were created during the period of the award. These include a Best junior/senior research project award –“Lung Nodule Classification Using Deep Learning” - in May 2019, and second place, in the Rowan Innovation Venture Fund Idea Challenge, for the project “Smart Bionics” in May 2018. Several undergraduate research summer internships were also offered to exceptional students.

A particular emphasis was placed on developing an entrepreneurial mindset by involving students with local industry, start-ups and developing stage companies, medical institutions, state and government agencies, through weekly progress meetings and presentations. The students had to balance innovation, real deliverables, and stakeholder involvement.

Assessment data was collected in a freshman Big Data module – including students from all six engineering disciplines - using a 10 question pre/post concept test. The data showed statistically significant improvement on the post-test compared to the pre-test. Comparison to a control group (students whose freshman section did a different project) showed that the improvement was attributable to the Big Data module, and not to the first-year experience in general. 

The Big Data undergraduate curriculum and integrated research projects – developed by the PI and her team - were instrumental in recruiting students to pursue graduate studies. 4 PhD students and 7 MS students in big data and computational intelligence joined the program after working on these junior/senior research projects. The graduated MS students are currently working with cutting-edge start-ups and Fortune 500 companies – keeping the entrepreneurial mindset, inspiring innovation, and building solutions to real-world problems.  

In collaboration with the Palmyra Cove Education Foundation, we conducted workshops for pre-college teachers to introduce them to Big Data via intense training in remote sensing and field observations. The workshops were conducted in New Jersey and Ohio. We also facilitated a learning environment that brings together pre-college teachers, students, engineering undergraduates, graduates, and stakeholders from the industry. 

 


Last Modified: 02/21/2022
Modified by: Nidhal Bouaynaya
